Digital Markets
text:
Hello,

Why do some markets get digitized with direct business to consumer (eg books, cars and stocks) but others still need a broker in between (eg commodities, housing)?

It cannot be the financial size of the transaction, as banks do a lot without any humans involved. On the other hand, commodity markets are almost exclusively using brokers. Does it have to do with how standard a product it is perhaps? Although commodities should be quite standard…

I tried searching google scholar and scihub, but I couldn’t find anything that gave me any reasonable explanation.

Ask HN: Engagement is lower, but people like the feature more
text:
I have a feature that makes recommendations. I track two metrics, are people using the feature, and do people think the feature is useful? Interestingly, these two numbers are diverging after a recent update: people are using the recommendations less, but they say that it’s working better too.

Is there a name for this scenario where people like a feature more when they’re using it less?

title: Convinced there’s an inside job/scam at Aus Gov Home Affairs website
text:
tl;dr I’m convinced there’s an inside job at Aus Gov Home Affairs website to drive traffic to an overcharging agency

So I got caught up in some weird scammy feeling shit today. I needed to apply for ETA going to Australia and went to https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/

There’s an absurdly long loading animation on their website. So much so I went back to google search results due to impatience.

I was on a phone call at the time, so was only half paying attention.

I found myself on australiagovisa.com speeding through a breezy UX, and like a classic noob happily punching in my credit card details.

I was promptly registered and got my visa soon thereafter delivered by email.

My friend comes along to do the same and points out this website is dodgy AF and has no official tie to Aus Gov.

So I panic a bit and worry I’m scammed, but I manage to load Immi website and check that my visa is in fact valid.

Later that eve I get charged $99 - Aus ETA is free via Immi website.

I’m convinced the dev for Immi has setup a timed delay to drive traffic to this agency and make a killing off impatient idiots like me.

Show HN: Fileport – Teleport Your Files
text:
Hello HN,

Fileport is an online service that provides the fastest way to send files over the internet.

Typically, email providers have file size restrictions and online cloud storage can be cumbersome to use. Fileport is the simplest way of transferring large files from point A to B. Intended for creative individuals like artists, video/audio editors, photographers showcasing their work or anyone whose work depends on exchanging large files.

Fileport is capable of “streaming” files to the recipient (or multiple recipients) as you upload them. You can upload multiple files or folders which can be downloaded in a compressed format, even while uploading. Files are automatically checksummed for integrity during the upload process.

There is a subscription available for users that require more features, like Photobooks. Photobooks are online photo & video albums that provide an ultra fast and clean web interface with all original files available for download.

Files up to 2 GB can be uploaded by anyone without the need of an account.

Ask HN: Software Engineering Management Tools
text:
There is a lot out there on various tech stacks. But a lot less about product stacks / software engineering management tools. Want to put together a list of tools to serve as a resource for company leaders that are less based on the technologies and more on best practices.

Application Monitoring (e.g. New Relic, Dynatrace) Server Monitoring (e.g. Ops View) Cloud Monitoring (e.g. Datadog) Cost Management (e.g. Flexera) Cloud Hosting (e.g. AWS/GCP/Azure) API Monitoring Test Automation (e.g. Applitools, Mabl) UX Testing (e.g. UserTesting) Release Testing (e.g. Applause) Build Management (e.g. Jenkins) Defect Management (e.g. JIRA) Project Management (e.g. JIRA) Requirements Management (e.g. JIRA) Log Management (e.g. Splunk, ELK) Road Mapping (e.g. Roadmonk) Code Base Analytics (e.g. KeyPup) Team Collaboration (e.g. Confluence) Test Case Management (e.g. Zephyr) Onboarding (e.g. Intercom) ChatBots (drift) Vulnerability Scanning (e.g. Veracode) Static Code Analysis (e.g. SonarQube) Data Integration (e.g. Talend) Cloud Data Management (e.g. Informatica) Customer Data Management (e.g. BlueConic) Customer Success (e.g. Gainsight) Notable SaaS Sales Software (e.g. Pipedrive / Xactly / Salesloft)
